Apparently, urlLink people aren't over Richard Clarke's interview on CBS' "60 Minutes" last month. The problem: a Viacom subsidiary published Clarke's book, Viacom owns CBS, and nobody said anything on the air about the fact that it was a Viacom business promoting a Viacom business. Media transparency is one thing. But should it make people any less suspicious of content? I say no. When "60 Minutes does its interview with Bob Woodward this week, urlLink some say the show will indeed mention that Viacom owns the company that is publishing Woodward's new tome. Cheers for the honesty, folks, but the point is, none of the other news shows' editors evidently believes that Woodward's book is important enough to plug on a prime time news magazine. None except the editor who works for the company that published the book. Transparency does not necessarily equate to newsworthiness. Of course, sometimes we can accept the newsworthiness of items, even if we need to look suspiciously at those items. When NBC reports on its parent General Electric's cleanup of the Hudson River, we should still be suspicous of any pro-GE commentary or angle, even though it's an obviously newsworthy item. We also have to watch out when PBS and NPR report on major contributors -- just because they tell us a company underwrites the particular program we're seeing or hearing, we shouldn't take what we see or hear at face value. We should question what is said, but we should also consider that the items are newsworthy. And if you want to talk about having to consider news items supspiciously, watch CNN sometime. The parent company own's AOL, Time Magazine, HBO, and just about every third CD you can find in your local record store, not to mention book publishing firms and movie studios. Oh yeah. And the Atlanta Braves. A quick overview of the networks: ABC is owned by the Walt Disney Corporation (I'm sure you've heard of them). NBC, as I mentioned, is a General Electric property (you know, light bulbs, washing machines, and Katie Couric), and will soon be paired with a number of Universal's property's (including cable networks Bravo and Telemundo and Universal film and music studios). CBS is a Viacom company -- they own Infinity Radio (which broadcasts Howard Stern to the world), Blockbuster, and a whole bunch of other stuff. Fox is owned by News Corporation, which mainly specializes in movies through such studios as 20th Century Fox and Fox Searchlight Films. News Corp. owner Rupert Murdock also owns the New York Post. urlLink MediaResearch , urlLink The Media Education Foundation , and urlLink MediaChannel are some excellent media literacy organizations. The Columbia Journalism Review's urlLink Who Owns What page lists many of the major media companies in the U.S. and Canada (as well as some abroad) and what they own. It can be good reading, especially if you've recently picked up, say, The Chicago Tribune recently, or tuned into one of the 1300 ClearChannel radio stations -- you used to be able to own 7 FM and 7 AM stations in the country, and then Reagan and Clinton came along and took care of that in two measures. Basically, big telephone companies -- the ones that built the U.S. telephone wire network -- are required to lease their lines to smaller companies that want to compete. It's an FCC requirement, and it's the only way that companies can compete for telephone service customers without building their own networks of wires (which would mean a new pole with wires between poles for each company that wants to provide service). Seem reasonable? I think so. But the Bells disagree. They say that because their monopolies were legal when they built the network and the government allowed them to pass along the costs of building the network to consumers, that the networks are public property. Not true -- if you or I wanted to start up a phone company, we'd need access to those lines for our customers' phones to work. The same problem is happening -- or should be happening -- in terms of cable television. Do you feel like you're paying too much for cable? Of course you do. Know why? Your town or city probably has one cable provider. If it has more than one, it's probably broken up by neighborhood so you still have a choice: cable or no cable -- not the choice of which cable company to go with. Cable companies lay their own cables in a city, and then contract with a city for service. Of course, if another company wants to contract with the city when the old contract is up, the new company either has to lease the cables from the company that laid them (assuming that company agrees to the lease), or has to lay its own infrastructure. Cable companies should have the same requirements as the Bells. The Bells laid the cables, and if anyone wants to use them, they should be required to lease their use from the Bells -- and in the interest of competition, the Bells should be required to lease them at reasonable rates. But the same should be true for cable companies -- that would increase competition and lower rates, and perhaps even increase the quality of cable service. urlLink E-mail me .

See? urlLink Here's what happens when you write a book citing almost entirely anonymous sources. People take you seriously, question things that happen, and riddle their opinions with words like "might," "maybe," "could have," and "perhaps." I'm not disputing the fact that funding for the war in Iraq is questionable. I'm not disputing the fact that we just plain old shouldn't be there. But the problem with opinion pieces based on Bob Woodward's new book is that the book might just be a bunch of Woodward rantings -- President Bush is reportedly the only one who went on record for the book, of the 75 or so sources not-exactly-cited. The problem with using anonymous sources is that as a reporter, you lose credibility. I understand that sometimes it's the only way to get information, or the only way to get people to let you use information. But Woodward's career has been based on anonymous sources -- and since his Watergate reporting (which featured Deepthroat, the mother of all anonymous sources, who was probably more like a half dozen anonymous sources), no one questions him. I suppose I should reveal facts about the times I have used anonymous sources. There are two different reasons I have used anonymous sources: (1) It's often the only way you can get government officials to criticize other government officials; (2) it is the only way to get information. Usually, with #2, someone is willing to give you the information anonymously, and then tell you who to call to get it on the record. The only time I wasn't able to get someone on the record for #2 was this: I got four Massachusetts state prison officials to tell me off the record that the reason it was better to have separate prisons for men and women was that there were concerns about the sexual environment, particularly with regards to the safety of women. One even said, "You know why, I know why, I just can't tell you on the record." But to write a whole book citing one source, and to pass it off as a major uncovering of facts is just, well, ridiculous. Maybe I can borrow it from the library and actually read it to tell you what I think, but I sure as heck can't shell out money and justify Woodward's use of anonymous sources. urlLink E-mail me .

Listen to this (audio-only) clip urlLink of a brief snippet from CBS' 60 Minutes . It's clear at the end that Mary J. Blige was going to say, "shit," whether or not you hear the whole word. The guy who got Howard Stern kicked off Clear Channel stations urlLink has submitted an FCC complaint on the broadcast . Whether or not you like it, certain words have crept into our vernacular. Bono and Blige -- who have used the words "fuck" and "shit" during recent broadcasts (OK, Bono's was a little over a year ago) as exclamatory phrases -- are not some young trash-mouthed kids with 10-word vocabularies. They're intelligent adults who have influence not just on the way kids see the world today, but in Bono's case, the world's politicians listen. I think we're moving into an age when context does matter. Bono's declaration that his receipt of an award was "fucking brilliant" was obviously an off-the-cuff remark with absolutely, positively, no intent to offend anyone. That particular broadcast was live with no delay, so censors could not have cut him off. And they shouldn't have, anyway. It just happens that that's the way Bono speaks. So what? He wasn't describing sexual acts or excretory functions -- which is what the law says is obscene -- so just let it go. Blige's exclamation, on the other hand, is a different situation. CBS had her saying, "shit," on tape, and could have edited it out. But you know what? It was an exclamation of disappointment, did not describe sexual acts or excretory functions, and furthermore, was broadcast on a show targeted at adults. Come on, adults, grow up. This is the way people talk now, and maybe broadcast regulations -- and some people's attitudes -- could be brought up to speed. "Damn" used to be unbearably offensive, and we've mostly grown past that now. Let's grow past "shit" and "fuck" as exclamations. Let's take words in context, and let's not go overboard. urlLink E-mail me .

Let's talk copyright infringement. Let's start with the urlLink RIAA dropping its download amnesty program . In case you've been living under a rock since copyright law came into being, it's illegal to distribute or receive copyrighted material without paying the copyright holder. It's called stealing . In case you've been living under a rock for the past few years, the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) thinks that the free receiving of music -- that is, downloading music for free off the Internet -- has been causing a huge decrease in the sales of CDs. Personally, I think it's the ridiculous prices on CDs mixed with a down economy. First, an aside. You can have a really really nice CD package put together for about $1.75 a disc if you're ordering 1,000 of them. If you're ordering more like 10 million of them, I'm sure that cost can come down to about 80 cents a disc. $100,000 would be just ridiculous for studio time (that's $200 an hour for 500 hours of work, and it doesn't take anyone that long to record an album -- if it does, you shouldn't be recording). Let's say a company puts in $1 million for marketing and distribution. We're up to, what? $9.1 million? Let's say that only 9 million discs sell, for an average of -- what do CDs cost now, $19? That's $171 million. Let's knock off, say, 20% for store markup. That comes to $127.7 million, and let's be nice and say the record company goes 50-50 with the artist (right, uh-huh). That's $63.85 million for the record company. At 15 songs on a CD, which I think is generous, that's over $4 million a song. In profit. With the same reasoning, people spent a bit over $1.20 a song, so that profit is finally eaten when over 3 million people get the song for free. The RIAA has been prosecuting "people" it says have been downloading songs for free. The reason "people" is in quotation marks (a la urlLink Jennifer Myszkowski ) is that mainly, the RIAA has been looking to prosecute IP addresses, which is how people are identified online. The thing is, service providers need to match the IP addresses with actual people, and most aren't willing to do so. So, the RIAA, representing record companies that share copyrights with artists, has been suing people for downloading free music on the Internet (which is what originally shut down urlLink Napster , which is back). Last September, the RIAA launched an amnesty program. People who had downloaded music for free (illegally -- see note about it being stealing ) were welcome to come forward, write down their names and addresses, and delete the songs from their computers, with the promise the RIAA wouldn't sue them. The Association stopped the program today, after 1,108 people had taken advantage of the program. The RIAA says it will honor the amnesty for those who had signed up. But what about the artists? It's bad enough that record companies get to share the artists' intellectual property. But let's say urlLink Shawn Mullins wants to sue somebody for downloading his music for free, and he has the person's IP address (not knowing who the person is), but that person has signed the amnesty agreement. Well, Columbia Records (a subsidiary of Sony) has promised not to sue, but Mullins hasn't. Now he has a name and address and everything, and it's all thanks to the amnesty program this person joined because he thought he wouldn't get sued. This, of course, is not to say that Mullins is looking to sue somebody (he's not, to the best of my knowledge), but I figured that since I had to pick an artist, I figured maybe you'd like to visit his Web site. So, really, did this program mean anything? Here's what I can offer, though. Visit urlLink my music page , and you can download the 9 songs up there for free, and if you don't sell them to other people (that's called stealing my money ) or try to claim them as your own, I won't sue you. urlLink E-mail me .

I offer you paragraph 3 of urlLink an article from Netscape News : "[Michael] Copps was one of two dissenters in the five-member [Federal Communications C]ommission's vote last June to ease regulations on media ownership. That ruling was motivated by the notion that the strict regulations in place -- intended to protect against monopoly of the airwaves -- became obsolete with the proliferation of such information and entertainment sources as the Internet and cable." Cable television and Internet access enter our homes when an adult voluntarily calls someone, asks for a service, and pays for it. Meanwhile, everybody pays for broadcast radio and television -- the public owns the airwaves, and through tax dollars funds the FCC, which is supposed to regulate things like ownership of radio stations. It used to be that a company could own 7 FM and 7 AM stations in the country. Now, a company can own 7 FM and 7 AM stations in a single market. In some markets, that means there is literally no competition. One line of thinking is, "So what? It doesn't matter who owns the stations, they'd all play the same music." Well, other than that being not true, there's a true matter of public responsibility -- and safety. We'll come back to responsibility in a moment. In terms of safety, if, say, the top 6 stations in one market are owned by one company, there will probably only be one office. That office is likely staffed with one or two disc jockeys per shift per station during the day (some stations will use pre-recorded or long-distance feeds during night-time -- and some day-time -- shifts), one producer/engineer per station, someone answering phones, and a single sales staff for all 6 stations. There's a shared news director, meteorologist, and traffic reporter for all the stations. If, during the day, a catastrophe hit that market, the vast majority -- maybe 85% -- of listeners would likely be listening to one of those stations. The single news director may or may not be able to get out of the office, and likely doesn't have any reporters to send out to actually see what's going on. If something happens to the company's broadcast antenna, 85% of listeners won't hear anything. If the catastrophe happens at night, chances are there's someone working for just above minimum wage making sure everything is on and there's no dead air, since everything has been pre-programmed. This person won't be able to report on the catastrophe, and indeed, there are no people for that company to go out and cover, say, a sudden flood or an earthquake -- disasters that people often first tune in to their radios to hear about. Then there's the responsibility a station has to offer a diversity of views. If a company is subscribing to a show -- say, Howard Stern or Rush Limbaugh -- the company will probably get a package deal for subscribing to the show for all 6 of its stations, so 85% of the listeners in the market will hear the same point of view. OK. I'm done for now. urlLink E-mail me if you wish.

urlLink Get it together . In case you're not sure how it works, this is the deal with the Nielsen ratings system. Every few months, AC Nielsen hands out these little boxes to "random" households. The boxes attach to the TV set, cable box, or satellite receiver (not the dish, the thing on the TV), and record what channel the TV is on when it's being watched. That's why stations pull out all the stops for "sweeps" month -- that's when Nielsen is doing its recording. The problem that has come about is that (surprise!) non-white neighborhoods are often left out of this "random" placing, meaning that shows aimed primarily at non-white audiences -- that is, shows with mainly non-white characters -- often come up with lower ratings than their actual viewership. Which means, of course, that the shows get cancelled sooner, and stations replace shows with a non-white focus with shows with white characters. In Bowling , when he and a shooting victim walked into K-Mart to "return the bullets" in the victim's back, all he did was manage to fluster a young, underpaid salesperson he knew would not be able to help him. This time, he takes his complaints straight to congresspeople, who actually can be responsible for the things he is asking for. Moore also gets his point across much better than he has in the past. I didn't watch urlLink John Kerry's speech . I knew it would be loaded with applause and energy because it had to be, and that I'd miss the substance, so I just decided I'd read it this morning. Before blogging about the speech, I read that Matt Yglesias urlLink thought it was "crap," but that urlLink it didn't matter what he thought , as he'd be voting for Kerry anyway. Josh Marshall's early thoughts are that the speech urlLink was "solid," and hopefully he'll elaborate on that. urlLink Jennifer said in an e-mail that she "got her cry on" a couple of times during the speech. I'm in the Yglesias camp. I live in typically Democratic-voting New York, and I'll be urlLink voting for Kerry anyway . But the content of the speech, I thought, dealt too much with the military, and was entirely what people wanted to hear , not what Kerry would actually do. That said, there are some passages I'd look at closer. "Mine were greatest generation parents. And as I thank them, we all join together to thank that whole generation for making America strong, for winning World War II, winning the Cold War, and for the great gift of service which brought America fifty years of peace and prosperity." Fifty years of peace and prosperity? Was that after World War II? A time period that included the Korean War, the Vietnam War, and Desert Storm, among the other places in which America interceded, including Afghanistan and Iran? "I will be a commander in chief who will never mislead us into war. I will have a Vice President who will not conduct secret meetings with polluters to rewrite our environmental laws. I will have a Secretary of Defense who will listen to the best advice of our military leaders. And I will appoint an Attorney General who actually upholds the Constitution of the United States." If Kerry struck a chord at all, it was here. Read very slowly, though, this part of the speech takes -- what, 40 seconds? -- to read, and as Matt pointed out, this was a long, not-so-detailed speech. Other than on the first line of that paragraph, Kerry doesn't elaborate on any of it (he says at one point that "Saying there are weapons of mass destruction doesn't make it so"). It really is just what people want to hear . "We're the can do people." This is probably just me, but I picture long rows of people walking in unison all wearing white t-shirts that say WE ARE CAN DO PEOPLE on the front, repeating in a high monotone, "Can do. Can do. Can do." "We value an America that controls its own destiny because it's finally and forever independent of Mideast oil. What does it mean for our economy and our national security when we only have three percent of the world's oil reserves, yet we rely on foreign countries for fifty-three percent of what we consume? "I want an America that relies on its own ingenuity and innovation not the Saudi royal family. "And our energy plan for a stronger America will invest in new technologies and alternative fuels and the cars of the future -- so that no young American in uniform will ever be held hostage to our dependence on oil from the Middle East." I would love to hear this energy plan. Does it require SUVs meet a 30 mpg city fuel efficiency standard? Does it require faster movement in developing lower cost hybrid vehicles? How about research into hydrogen as a mass-market fuel? Or is it instead going to bring back the days of oil rationing, cutting down on commutes (which can only hurt one's ability to work) and vacations (which can only hurt the tourist industry)? Where are the details?

I won't go through Illinois State Senator Barack Obama's life story -- urlLink The New Yorker and urlLink The Atlantic can do that for you. But I am going back through his urlLink convention speech , which, as I was watching it last night, seemed intelligent, smart, and moved me in a way that no speech from a Democrat has moved me -- ever. I'm going to pull out quotes of note for you. "Tonight, we gather to affirm the greatness of our nation, not because of the height of our skyscrapers, or the power of our military, or the size of our economy. Our pride is based on a very simple premise, summed up in a declaration made over two hundred years ago, 'We hold these truths to be self-evident, that all men are created equal. That they are endowed by their Creator with certain inalienable rights. That among these are life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.' "That is the true genius of America, a faith in the simple dreams of its people, the insistence on small miracles." Obama's choice of the urlLink Declaration of Independence as a source to quote might be trite for a politician, but probably still holds plenty of excitement for the child of an immigrant. And I really like the "small miracles" bit. It just feels warm and fuzzy, which most politicians just aren't these days. "And fellow AmericansDemocrats, Republicans, IndependentsI say to you tonight: we have more work to do. More to do for the workers I met in Galesburg, Illinois, who are losing their union jobs at the Maytag plant thats moving to Mexico, and now are having to compete with their own children for jobs that pay seven bucks an hour." Here in Syracuse, this rings true -- all except the $7/hr part, which here reads $5.15/hr minimum. That I'm having trouble finding a place to apply to for part-time work, never mind to actually work at, is unusual. It's because Nestle, Carrier, Kraft, Ethan Allen and others just keep closing up here, putting several thousand people out of work (this is since I moved here a year ago), and driving people who had been with their companies for an average of almost 30 years and making an average of about $17/hour to the mall food court. I've never before bought a Times at a newsstand where, when it's slow, the minimum wage worker behind the counter was dying for an intelligent conversation as to what was in the paper. "A belief that we are connected as one people. If theres a child on the south side of Chicago who cant read, that matters to me, even if its not my child. If theres a senior citizen somewhere who cant pay for her prescription and has to choose between medicine and the rent, that makes my life poorer, even if its not my grandmother. If theres an Arab American family being rounded up without benefit of an attorney or due process, that threatens my civil liberties. Its that fundamental beliefI am my brothers keeper, I am my sisters keeperthat makes this country work. Its what allows us to pursue our individual dreams, yet still come together as a single American family. 'E pluribus unum.' Out of many, one." This is where I kind of perked up last night. John Edwards spent a lot of his primary campaign talking about "Two Americas," but it's clear just by looking at him that he's no longer a part of the one that he came from. But it was unclear to me throughout the campaign how Edwards planned to connect to the "other" America. Obama freely admits that he's different from an illiterate child, a poor senior citizen, and others, but he recognizes that when others around him have a greatly lessened quality of life, his quality of life is lessened, and he wants to do something about it. That's a vision I can get behind. Oddly, though, the text of the speech seems to be cut on the Dems' Web site. I'm certain Obama said something about erasing the notion that a black child carrying a backpack full of books is acting white or some such thing. It's through this notion of equality, of erasing lines between race, income, etc., that I feel Obama connected so well to people, and he's doing it better than people have in the best in terms of political success. Martin Luther King, Malcolm X and Jesse Jackson have all been out somewhere on the fringe despite the large number of people they were able to rally; Obama, on the other hand, may very well become only the third black senator ever.

Jack Shafer has some urlLink pretty harsh words for Ben Bagdikian, who has just released urlLink The New Media Monopoly , which is really just the seventh edition of The Media Monopoly , which was first published in 1983 (the sixth edition came out in 2000). Not having read the seventh edition, I can't vouch specifically for or against his criticisms of the book, but indeed through the first six editions, Bagdikian moved from largely criticizing the newspaper industry to bigger media companies like Time Warner and Disney. Shafer writes that the old criticisms of the newspaper industry are probably still valid, and gosh darn it, I think he's right. Newspapers are in the unique position of being able to come out reasonably quickly -- much more quickly than the weekly newsmagazines -- but not so quickly that they pounce on a story with one eye closed just trying to beat their competitors by 10 minutes like the 24-hour television news channels. Newspapers can sit back for a little while on a story, watch the immediate repercussions, and explain to readers the impact a story may have on them. But perhaps not enough of them do. USA Today is the most circulated paper in the country. Over 2 million people pick it up Monday through Friday, and if it is assumed that each copy is read by two people (figuring that a number of copies might be read by entire households of five or six), four million people get their news from that source. The paper is owned by Gannett, which owns urlLink several hundred other newspapers in the U.S. and U.K., along with some television stations and joint ventures that include the Major League Baseball team the Cincinnatti Reds, a national career search network, and a national classified advertising network. The career search and classified advertising networks, incidentally, are joint ventures with some of the other largest U.S. newspapers chains in terms of circulation. Meanwhile, USA Today , which reaches perhaps 4 million readers, revolutionized the news industry when it was launched in 1981 by running short snippets of news. Because the paper was so profitable, many other newspapers have followed suit. And you know what that means, right? Right. Half-assed newspaper stories that amount to 30 second television spots and don't explain events and their implications. Even when newspapers take the time to explain events and, say, newly passed legislation to readers, under the bigger corporate structure, they have little incentive to make clear the implications for particular communities. It's much cheaper to either (a) buy wire service stories, or (b) share news amongst its newspapers. The New York Times is known for being amoung the country's best news sources (despite its former lack of a policy on anonymous sources, as we found out in the Jayson Blair case -- the company now has a new policy, available for download urlLink here ), but why make the news pertain to New Yorkers when folks who read the Boston Globe and the Times' urlLink other papers in Ocala, Fla., Lexington, N.C., and Petaluma, Calif., would read the same story? Sharing stories across newspapers is something a lot of companies do -- in fact, the urlLink Springfield (Mass.) Republican , a urlLink Newhouse publication, has been known to run full series of stories that originated at other Newhouse papers about goings on in towns that the people of Western Massachusetts care little about. The lesson in all of this is, be sure to read multiple news sources. Be sure to question what you see in print, and look to alternative news sources for stories that might not otherwise be reported. Don't assume that just because media (print or otherwise) give big play to a story, a story is important.

Every few weeks, I try to get together with Kai Wang, a Taiwanese student who for the last year has been taking his masters degree in public relations at urlLink SUs Newhouse School . Kais bringing Monica along, it turns out, is part of what I think is a wonderful tradition: When Taiwanese students decide to come to Newhouse, they are given contact information (independently of the school) of other Taiwanese students who have already been at the school for a year. The veteran students take the new students under their wing, picking them up from the airport, showing them around town, making sure they are able to find an apartment, etc. To show how vastly different this is from the way Americans act at the school: When Mary Beth Ray, who starts next month in Newhouses media studies program, came to a prospective students day on campus, she was fairly shocked to find that the school did not have in place a program wherein current students offer their couches for the night to people traveling long distances to see the program.
